text: weird question... Do any of you have "mentors" and if so, is it "helpful"? How did you find a "mentor"?

elements.text: weird question... Do any of you have "mentors" and if so, is it "helpful"? How did you find a "mentor"?

text: <@UPUBAM63X>¸ not weird at all! I have had several mentors throughout my life who have helped mold me into the person I am today - I am forever indebted to them! In terms of helpfulness, I would say that something that has guided me to mentors is the notion of finding someone who is doing something I am thoroughly interested in but I am _not quite there yet_. Be it in programming or philosophy or mathematics, the way I generally find mentors is to see someone who is doing the thing that I am interested in and figuring out a way to work with them. One of my mentors was a co-worker who taught me a ton about linux and information technology - in return, I helped provide IT support when he was preoccupied. Another was a friend who was working on a project and wanted help - I was interested but nowhere near the skill level he was at. However, he still wanted me to come aboard and help - that made me a better software developer.

text: But I have nothing but good stuff to say about my phd advisor. The man was basically my second dad. Infact, I just had drinks at his house last weekend since we've become very close friends.

text: I'm asking mostly because - I find myself running in circles professionally. Some of that is me trying to square away my personal life, but some of it isn't. I've mentored some people in the past, but never had strong mentorship personally. My advisors(in grad school) both realized I was disciplined enough to see things through and left me to do the work. My second advisor saved my Ph.D though, I basically said to myself I was going to leave with a Masters degree if I wasn't allowed to switch groups. He took me in and I owe him and the field I'm in that level of effort.
